title: 114_hr4370
content: The "Compact Impact Relief Act of 2016" is also known as the Compact Impact Relief Act. It includes an adjustment for affected jurisdictions equivalent to Compact migrant expenditures. The "Compact Impact Relief Act of 2016" increases the FMAP for affected jurisdictions based on estimated Compact migrant expenditures. The chief executive official must submit expenditure estimates to the Secretary of the Interior for review before adjustments are made and submitted to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services estimates the increase in FMAP for affected jurisdictions based on Compact migrant expenditures. The increase in FMAP cannot exceed limitations under the Social Security Act. Notification must be given 30 days before adjustments are made. The Secretary of Health and Human Services notifies chief executive officials of FMAP increases 30 days before the quarter. Chief executive officials submit migrant expenditure reports to the Secretary of the Interior for review and adjustments. The Secretary of Health and Human Services reviews and adjusts migrant expenditure reports submitted by chief executive officials to ensure accurate Federal payments under title XIX of the Social Security Act. Adjustments to the Federal Medical Assistance Percentage (FMAP) for affected jurisdictions may be made for future quarters based on the final accounting of compact migrant expenditures. The FMAP for affected jurisdictions may be adjusted for future quarters based on compact migrant expenditures, with a limit of 100 percent. Compact migrant expenditures are non-Federal funds spent on items and services in the jurisdiction. The FMAP for affected jurisdictions may be adjusted based on compact migrant expenditures, with a limit of 100 percent. This includes funds expended for items and services under the Social Security Act for qualified nonimmigrants and related administrative costs. Payments to healthcare providers for nonimmigrants must not be made under a State plan or from other Federal funds. The term "FMAP" refers to the Federal medical assistance percentage. A conforming amendment to the Social Security Act is made regarding the Compact Impact Relief Act of 2016. SEC. 3. PAYMENTS RELATING TO ELEMENTARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION OF CITIZENS OF FREELY ASSOCIATED STATES. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include educating alien children from the Freely Associated States as citizens of the United States. Additionally, payments for eligible federally connected children now include those who resided in the US as citizens of the Republic of the Marshall Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia, or the Republic of Palau. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include additional funding for eligible federally connected children, authorizing $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2017 and each succeeding year. This funding applies to children described in section 8003(a)(1) under the Act. SEC. 4 amends the Housing and Community Development Act of 1980 to give preference to U.S. citizens or nationals over aliens for housing financial assistance in Guam and the Northern Mariana Islands. SEC. 5 calls for an independent assessment of the strategic relationship between the U.S. and the Marshall Islands, Micronesia, and Palau. The Secretary of State seeks an agreement with an organization to assess the strategic importance of the US relationship with the Marshall Islands, Micronesia, and Palau, including their role in the Asia-Pacific region and the effectiveness of US agencies in administering agreements and financial support. The eligible organization will provide support to the Republic of Palau, make recommendations for improvements, changes to processes, and future administration of Compacts and financial support. A report must be submitted to the Secretary of State within one year, including assessments, recommendations, and any other relevant matters. The report will be in unclassified form, with a classified annex if necessary. The eligible organization may obtain official data directly from US departments or agencies to carry out the agreement. The head of the department or agency must provide the information upon request.
